projects.title: aMRI
projects.subtitle: the functional MRI implies the existence of an afunctional MRI
description: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imagery aims to understand what part of our brain, associated with specific functions, use the most energy given certain tasks. This is useful for physicians and other experts to analyze brain functions, advance science, and understand brain-related injuries and diseases better.
Though it communicates information that are closest to us, fMRI results remain complex and innaccessible information for most . Its affordances are for experts to understand.

Another function of this kind of imagery could be to communicate information to ourselves in a more humanist and personal way. Simplifying convoluted data by removing layers of scientific accuracy would be naive, but it may make information more reachable, thus more meaningful.

There is no pain nerve endings in the brain, so imaging brain functions help us gain awareness of those functions better, and our own situatedness within them. Although we cannot actually feel them, seeing them may emulate a similar sensation.

The afuntional MRI makes you reflect on a general idea, and asks where in your brain you think this may come from. Is it a random choice, or do you know the brain enough to guess with precision? Which functions do you think visualizing those data may have? In the most non-scientific way possible, why is it important to reflect where in your brain things come from?

projects.title: Data_Scapes
projects.subtitle: data story-telling
description: Data_scapes is a continuing exploration of story-telling through data and folk ontologies; how we can reinterpret different stories through different simplified data visualization and algorithms. Humanity has naturalized hegemonic, yet arbitrary, structures and hierarchies in every aspect of our existence, including cyberspace. Our deterministic rather than probabilistic nature, that is we would rather want something to be entirely true or entirely false, as opposed to a nuance of both or neither, forces oversimplifications of natural, organic, and non-linear processes into binary ‘truths’.  This makes us increasingly less likely to accept different ‘subjective’ truths as equally ‘objective’ amongst themselves.

Data_scapes seeks to visualize complex notions by removing intermidiary steps and noise of inference processes and data collection, instead prioritizing user exploration of different visualizations of the same raw data, their geolocation, to tell different, sometimes diverging, stories.
What would happen if we would learn to see different versions of reality as equally true, depending on how and when we come to calculate them?

projects.title: Data Patterns
projects.subtitle: A study of collaborative garment creation between human and machine
description: Data patterns is an exploration of collaborative artistic methodologies between machines and humans. Ai processes have generally been designed to become humans’ workers, consequently antagonizing the machine and perceiving it as a replacement for, namely, artists’ and designers’ practices.

This philosophy has restrained the development of such creative methodologies; we fail to perceive them as an addition to the designer’s toolbox, but also as a collaborative agent for artistic practices. By (re)imagining heterodox and creative methodologies between human and machine, data patterns fosters critical and social imaginaries for the future of ‘AI art’ and the artist’s ever-evolving practice.

projects.title: Shein’s Cabinet of Curiosities
projects.subtitle: and why the algorithm thought you’d like it
description: Giant corporations and retailers like Shein use powerful algorithms that collect personal information from users and clients to infer on products produced in real time. They then specifically target some for you when you visit their website based on what they believe you will like and purchase.

As a way of reflecting on what companies like these know about us through extraction of personal data, scroll through Shein’s product pages and find the most curious products that are offered to you. On the product’s detail page, use the Shein’s Cabinet chrome extension to write a short prompt of your choosing.
Why do you think this product was targetted to you? Where or when would you wear it? What is it meant for?
Downloading this google extension on your own machine will grant you access to all journal entries.
Presented at fourth space (2022) as part of _scapes project mediation

projects.title: Les rideaux de ma mère
projects.subtitle: My mom's curtains
description: Femme is a short animation depicting an ambiguous female form, with her insides mounted on her head and shoulders. She is arched slightly inward, looking into the absence of her abdomen. Her larger-than-nature body is stripped of limbs, stuck between the walls of a 3D rendition of Concordia University’s agora. This sculpture is an ode to universal bodily autonomy and a consideration of body dysmorphia, the unscientific and socially constructed lack of institutional freedom people affected by either live through, and the mental discord it entails.

projects.title: Æffect
projects.subtitle: A prototype for a contemplative wearable
description: In our fast-paced society and beset by the challenges of pandemic facial coverings, our connection to both our own emotional condition and the condition of others has seemingly never been further from our conscious awareness. A portmanteau of visual effect and psychological affect, Æffect presents a prototype model for a physically dynamic, emotionally responsive wearable garment providing haptic feedback to its wearer to encourage greater introspection.

projects.title: Ad Vitam Aeternam
description: Tasked to design an ‘unrealistic’ garment without material or commercial restrictions, I aimed to produce an environmentally sustainable concept that centers clothes’ life cycles and their striking ecological impact. From extensive research on sustainable manufacturing and production processes I had started in my internship at Vestechpro, an innovative apparel research center, I designed a speculative wearable that would allow a giving back rather than an ever-increasing taking; the fashion industry’s usual approach to production.

Ad vitam aeternam is an exploration of what living and dressing within our situated materialities can look like; a manifest garment created from wood pulp housing living and growing local flora. The 3D printed structure , housing whichever floral species found where worn, could be assembled onto a body or be disposed outside to create a garden; a quite feasible and realistic way of wearing a flower pot.

projects.title: Un jeu d'Enfant
projects.subtitle: Child's play
media: garments (tweed, silk chiffon linin, white shirting)
description: As part of my last fashion design studies collection, we were tasked to produce a collection based on the theme Crayola. The brand’s bright colors and patterns inspired me to mirror in clothes the youthfulness I always refused to let go when introduced to adulthood.

Playful and childlike silhouettes were created with a juvenile short-skirt (skort) and overall, while handmade hama beads button, melted Crayola wax onto otherwise pristine white shirting fabric, and backpack clips completed an otherwise modern feminine look inspired by fashion’s most iconic cuts, namely Chanel’s four-pocket jacket.

projects.title: Monastique
projects.subtitle: End of studies fashion collection
description: Monastique,  an imposed theme for my end of degree collection, called for elegant minimalism, and inspired seemingly simple, yet technically complex, garment pieces. The solemn and sober shapes of the garment allowed for several material modifications and technical audacities to elevate the look elegantly. Manually laminated fabric and ultrasonic bonding were used to create a simili-leather look, while a loosened overlock gave way to handstitch look-alikes.

experiments.title: TouchDesigner
experiments.subtitle: Subtitle
description: As I complete my internship (CART-456) at the Computation Lab, and with it my BFA in Computation Arts, I must archive the steps that lead me here, doing the library that I am starting. I first want to reiterate my initial goals, and how they morphed into what I achieved. I will then further explain what notions of TouchDesigner I explored and why. I will conclude by positioning the foundations of my project with my final reflections.

iterations.title: Goals and Beginnings
description: What I wanted from an internship at the Computation Lab was first and foremost mentorship from Sabine Rosenberg. I appreciate her pedagogical skills a lot, and her meaningful feedback has always propelled my practice where it needed to be, and myself towards questions I needed to ask. After completing both Networks courses with her and having HCI become an (unexpected) interest of mine, I knew I could not leave it at that. Although those courses showed me more new tools than perhaps the rest of my degree combined, I still felt I needed to learn something else; a framework that would wrap all my skills together and allow “trans” disciplinary, interactive, and real-time experimentations.

Inspired to take my creative coding skills further, I aimed to learn a lower-level creative framework that would allow me granular control over functions. I first thought of OpenFrameWorks, as I am somewhat more comfortable with C++, aside from the HTML/CSS/JS (php) holy trinity. TouchDesigner’s Python base intimidated me at first, as I overestimated its usage in simpler networks (although it does pick up when you are trying to make OSC work properly). The framework’s node system also appeared more constraining than a conventional coding structure. After more research and conversation with Sabine, I nevertheless opted to learn TouchDesigner instead of OpenFrameWorks. I was still not entirely sold (still not sure I am), but the infinite online resources and community, its current relevance in new media art, and my goals of learning a comprehensive interactive creative coding tool made it the most compelling framework to learn.

As part of my internship, I also wanted to practice teaching by giving workshops. I love assisting folks with their own projects and ideas, figuring out how others think through their challenges and bugs, and helping them figuring it out along the way. Preparing and teaching a workshop on P5 made me realize how much more work than anticipated this portion of my internship would produce. When teaching, I not only need to know the technology thoroughly, but I also need to create projects with it that are easily explainable and replicable. Explaining JS notions to first- and second-year CART students helped me recognize I knew more than I thought I did about coding (there’s always so much more to learn, it’s hard to see what has already been achieved). Although I feel comfortable challenging myself with large-scale creative coding projects, programming something for yourself to understand is very different from programming something for learners to understand. After pulling off one workshop at the beginning of the semester, I recognized that doing more than that would largely impact how much resources I could put into my own project, so I decided to leave it at that. I still learned a lot, especially from Sabine’s feedback, and I am looking forward to being able to put those skills into practice at a later point in my career.

iterations.title: TouchDesigner
description: I started TouchDesigner from absolute scratch, having completed one (1) student-led Python workshop and assuming the Node system was going to be like Blender’s. Wrong, wrong, wrong. I am thankful to Sabine for forcing me to complete the 100 series before falling into unnecessary rabbit holes I could not understand the depths of yet. With those bite sized tutorials, I was able to understand what and where the most used operators were. Without building any complex networks (which was boring, I must admit), I got to understand the context of TD’s node system. Apart from familiarizing myself with nodes and operators, I also slowly learned Python expressions for TD (TScript). Other than some browser-based protocols like PHP, I did not have a broad understanding of networked data transmission like OSC, DMX, etc. Spending some time documenting myself on the terminology of most things made the research process much more efficient when came time to build bigger (more complex) networks.

iterations.title: TD / instancing
description: Aiming to find parallels I could understand between this new framework and ones I knew, I started learning about the Instancing parameters of the Geo Component from TD as a (far-fetched) mirror to JS’s OOP notions. The Geo Component’s instancing parameters allow Surface Operators (3D objects) a similar behaviour as JS OOP’s constructor method, in the way it creates individual instances of an object given programmed (and variable) parameters. Learning to program is a steep learning curve at first, but once you understand the syntax of one language, it is often simpler to learn a new one. I assumed a similar thing would happen while teaching myself TD, and that forcing JS behaviour unto TD functionalities would ultimately output the desired effect. However, if JS functionalities are what would be preferable in a given context, why would I ever go towards a TD network? Instead of forcing my understanding of creative (‘linear’) programming into my experiments, I took a step back, trusted the process with a few more tutorials, and tried to approach TD as the node-based framework it is, using the advantages it had over my beloved JS.

iterations.title: TD / noise
description: Randomness and chaos (theory) are big interests of mine, and TD’s Noise operators can create very interesting effects using these concepts. They were an intuitive first step for me to learn about some operators’ effects without being constrained to complex changing data input (like human interaction, sound input, etc.). However, TD’s high-level functionality, which makes prototyping qualitative interactive audio-visual renditions with little programming knowledge, also comes at a cost. More nuanced approach to interaction, noise, and HCI must be taken to avoid falling in a commercially leaning (and oversaturated) aesthetic. Noise operators are a great tool for quickly prototyping lower fidelity ideas and can be nicely layered with other interactions and effects, but I have found they would likely not be the end goal of my TD based projects. I had to find more.

iterations.title: TD /  I/O & CV
description: Two of TD’s strengths are its range of supported data transmission, and Computer Vision (CV) and other video processing models. I aim for my projects to create embodied experiences, while remaining accessible and un-intrusive. I am personally more attuned to electronics and interactive artistic experiences, but I create for audiences that do not have to be. For me, this means that a participant needs to feel welcomed into an interaction without ever feeling trapped in it. I started exploring camera input as I felt this was a good way of letting an audience interact as passively or actively as they wanted. By creating a sliding scale of afforded experiences, my goal is always to introduce some chaos, and TD’s (actual) sliding system and exportable parameter expressions allow for such serendipity to occur.

Going through a few options, I completed simple networks using the Sim Zig app and the Iphone’s front camera depth and alpha map, as well as its face skeleton using OSC UDP transmission. Sim Zig is a great prototyping tool I will go back to, as it allows comprehensive and simple models (especially the full body skeleton and face) input to TouchDesigner in no time. It is however not accessible enough to be a final prototype’s input, as it is only usable with iPhone sensors and OS. I then explored TD’s native Blob Track (TOP) Operator, that tracks blobs with a subtracted background (or not). Working on TD’s free version limited the blob limit to 2, which is realistically 1 jittering blob. Without a consistent and known background to subtract the possible blobs from, the operator failed to provide enough usable information on embodied events.

I then switched to Torinmd’s MediaPipe external TD plugin, available as an open-source downloadable patch from his Github. The plugin, given a camera input, outputs MediaPipe’s human and object tracking, as well as image classification, and several image segmentation models on specific CHOP and TOP output operators. The free add-on is surprisingly reliable and allowed a ton of easy experimentations with a simple standard quality webcam. There are a ton of ‘embodied’ tools for TD I could pull from open-sources, and I hope to discover a lot more.  For the current needs however, MediaPipe felt more than sufficient, and I still wanted to explore other data inputs and their plausible visual inference. I kept going.

iterations.title: TD / Radio Digital Signal Processing
description: As my interest for electromagnetic waves, radio frequencies, and the information-filled noise they carry, grew, I dived into Channel Operators (CHOPs). I do not consider myself a sound person at all, and I was struggling to know how most useful this (huge) part of TD could be to my practice. I researched Digital Signal Processing software programs like FLDigi that could visualize and archive radio’s digital modes’ waterfall display (a 3D map of a spectrograph (z) of a range of frequencies (x) over time (y)). I then succeeded at emulating an accurate waterfall DSP display on TD. These TD waterfalls are not more or less informative than FLDigi’s or another modem’s one, although the modem does allow an accurate decoding of the frequency into its (humanly) intelligible data, which TD is not capable of. What TD is good at doing however, is mapping otherwise unrelated data together through expressions, making them behave in relation to one another. This opens the affordances of inference from a single audio file (of electromagnetic frequencies) to many output, like 3D objects and environment, movement and animations. These reinterpretations of digital signal processing into speculative audio-visual renditions can inform new ways of perceiving otherwise ‘invisible’ data, which I find absolutely fascinating!

iterations.title: TD_snippets library implementation
description: Understanding the high-level to low-level shifts that TD allows helped me develop an efficient prototyping methodology with the framework. The node system enabled me to prototype small experiments quickly, and tweak all components to specific details needed by my projects. As opposed to a conventional and ‘linear’ approach to programming, where I need a clear end goal in mind when I start coding, I have learned to explore and modify parameters, and see where it takes me. If coding feels like painting, TD feels like sketching. Once satisfied, one can take their black marker and immortalize a good enough sketch. However, it will probably always be best to recreate the sketch on another, more elegant, medium. Most of what TD is capable of can be achieved outside of the software, with better and more efficient protocols. It would just take an unrealistic amount of R&D to achieve the smallest prototype for limited production teams. Using TD, I was able to prototype a preview of our interactive Symphenia (2024) project and modify it weeks before we were able to render the final output on LED matrices. It saved our team a lot of resources in time and money, as well as tears, probably.

TD has a lot of limitations, however. They act as middleware for many technologies they house (like MediaPipe, Python (libraries), to name a few), which can again be very powerful while prototyping and experimenting, but frustrating in the production phase when all elements need to be stabilized and optimized. TD is especially finicky for importing external Python libraries, making more complex programming a headache within a patch. Communication anomalies also seemed to occur when communicating to edge devices like Raspberry Pi by OSC over ethernet, which did not appear to cause issues in vanilla python scripts. Though I was able to work through the issues this time around, it still seems to be a safer bet to transpose the production network in another, more stable, environment if possible. TD’s versatility is probably its best and most challenging quality. As a jack of all trade, it allows prototyping between many devices and parameters’ mapping in a fraction of the time that hard-coding a stable version would take. Perhaps a master’s of none, TD is a framework I will dive more in-depth with, especially to create quick sketches and ideas, moving forward.

I wanted my internship at the CLAB to be a culmination of all of my time, with the skills I already had mixed with the ones I acquired, in my Computation Arts degree at Concordia. I learned a new framework that compliments my own transdisciplinary, quirky (and sometimes unstable) practice. TD’s crux relies in how easy layering and tweaking smaller chunks of operators into complex networks is. While learning, creating and feeding a library of TD snippets has already made prototyping projects that much more streamlined and efficient. As opposed to a full-fledged production size project, I will use TD for what I have learned it is the best at, (you guessed it) prototyping. By creating this library, I am building the foundations of an open-source toolbox of my own TD snippets and patches, which will eventually gain in complexity as my comfort with the framework increases. My practice has always centered community-driven approaches to innovation and knowledge sharing. I believe an important and natural next time for my creative coding journey is to build onto that idea of learning as much as I can, and sharing what I know. This internship has offered me the opportunity to start this TD_snippets library, which I will keep feeding on my own. I hope it will become a resource future students of the CLAB find useful. The link to github repository of this library can be found at the top of this page (TD_snippets library button).

iterations.title: Final reflections
description: I thought my internship at the Computation Lab would be the best opportunity to share my acquired knowledge with Computation Arts students less familiar with creative coding, but I underestimated how much I still needed to learn from the lab and Sabine (and Elio, but do not let him know). The motivation and patience to assist confused (and sometimes confusing) students was challenging to find (almost as if lab tech and teaching were full time jobs). Although I am satisfied with how much and what I learned this semester, if I were to complete another internship in an academic setting, I would choose to make either a research project or a full teaching series of some sort, but not both in the same ‘contract’. The marathon of event-planning, preparing and teaching realistic workshops was slightly less rewarding than the chaotic sprint of a large-scale idealistic project. I had the stamina to assist students at the beginning of the semester when they needed it the least. At the end of the semester however, I did not have the initiative to assist them, as I was too pressed by my own projects’ developments and getting my own Sabine and Elio sponsored debugs (almost as if being a student was a full-time job). I recognize that the help and tutoring I wanted to provide to other students did not unfold the way I planned it during my internship, but I am grateful from what I learned from my challenges and will apply those lessons in future teaching experiences.

Even while working on my own projects, doing so in the CSLAB under the mentorship of Sabine, in addition to the symbiotic assistantship I found with students who frequent the lab, brought a lot more to my practice than any other course could. The community I found in the Computation and Sensor Labs with Sabine, Elio, visiting faculty, and the DCART+ students often felt like the only real cohort I had during my degree. The conversations fostered in that space have always animated and inspired all the students I know, myself included and foremost. Sabine’s knowledge and reference base will never surpass any syllabus I could find myself confronted with. I have also always found her feedback to not only be meaningful, but meticulously attuned to students’ own goal with their given prompts. Studying at and for the Computation lab has pushed me to become a better version of the student I am and shown me the kind of teacher I aspire to become. There are always things that could be improved, I am aware I did not fulfill all my promises, but I am satisfied with the completion of this internship. I want to extend my gratitude to Sabine and Pippin, for trusting me with this do-over and my idiosyncratic way of going about this endeavour. Thanks to your patience, I was able to take the required time to learn a new framework, build the foundations of my own library, and share a lot with a bunch of students, which is what I have always wanted to do.
